comments.commentBody:
Reply Mark Thomason:

Don't forget Indira Gandhi, Prime Minister of India:

"In 2001, Gandhi was voted the greatest Indian Prime Minister in a poll organised by India Today. She was also named "Woman of the Millennium" in a poll organised by the BBC in 1999."

The daughter of Nehru, she was raised in a political family and served two terms, dealing with tumultuous events and sectarian divides, resulting in her assassination in 1984 by two sectarian extremists, members of her own personal security guard.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indira_Gandhi
Indira Gahndi, Golda Meir.
As others have commented, most, if not all of the women mentioned did not wear the title of "President".  Perhaps, in the context of the original post, the term "leader" would be more appropriate.

Fun to read, but past is not prologue...necessarily. The world has known women presidents and, generally speaking, with as good a record as men, although I suspect less war-mongering, given they are prone to preserve our species (in more ways than one). Hillary seems as good as any candidate, and it would be foolish to assume she can't win. She is a winner already, irrespective of prospective results.
Serious crimes? He never spent time in the pen or somehow, was lucky, or did the right things to keep free from that! He was a very unfortunate man who was thrust into a cold world!

I agree with Ray to an extent.  While our society should do its best to provide the best possible care for those in need of remedial help, shouldn't we be a society that cares most about avoiding harm to its citizens?  You have problems, as do I, but as a result I don't deserve to suffer or die.  For our plans why do we focus on you, and not I?
It seems like he went looking for "validation" in a broken and hollow "gangsta" culture.   What a dead end.
Yup. Someone else's fault.

I despise what he did, but I feel terribly sorry for this lonely, pathetic man dying for validation who just could not get a life together that worked.  Another invisible human being screaming to be noticed for all the wrong reasons and no one noticing for long enough to offer any real solid support and stability.  I know, I know - he was responsible for himself, but we are social creatures and not designed to be so alone and isolated and always, always struggling.  At some point, despair and hopelessness takes over.  Clearly that happened here.  This story is tragic on so many levels, the shock waves of which, I believe, will be felt for a very, very long time.

Tough puzzle, as expected on Saturday. Many passes through the clues to make progress, along with a break to teach Merri something on her Kindle.

Then suddenly, MPH pops up. I didn't realize I was done until then.
As of this writing, 46 readers liked this comment. I had to read it three times to really get that you were saying that breaking up the United States would be a positive.

Surely, the Rickster can recognize sarcasm.

Ah, a new year, and we have perhaps two more revolutions around the sun before we cease reading the word "Jebster" from Sir Richard.

Oy vey.
He still believes he has credibility when it comes to predicting presidential elections
It's probably true that Hillary wouldn't follow in the footsteps of James Buchanan and allow any southern states to secede.  On the other hand, I'd vote for absolutely anyone who would.

I share your disgust. The rich (especially the "nouveaux" kind) have always been superficial. But with the popularity of the "Real Housewives" reality type shows, superficial is now on steroids.
Although I am an American, I am so grateful that my granddaughter is being brought up in Toronto!
I too am disgusted. But this behavior has nothing to do with feminism or feminists.  It is the very opposite of those values.

I don't understand your last sentence. This story is about an anti-feminism permeating our society. For an appropriate view for bringing up strong girls who are not superficial, check out the blog A Mighty Girl; it's a fantastic source.

Now I've seen everything; these are children? - crikey. Spare me, and my family that's all I can say.
As granny used to say, common sense isn't that common.

These are superficial adults, raising precociously superficial kids, but super-superficial; Have they written poetry? read Antoine de St Exupery's The Little Prince? Learned how to be empathic? How are their arpeggios? enjoyed Matisse's paintings? eaten artichokes with lemon? Admired the architecture of Florence? Cooked Crêpes Suzette? Learned how to change tires? Found out how to Please please, give this ludicrous behaviour up. These kids should sue their brain-dead parents for neglect - neglect of their childhood. Typically American - the very worst.

You; super-rich! pay attention; you are brain-dead and you don't even know it. Please just pay your taxes and get out of here. nails? what's next? Perms? Brazillians? Breast implants at age 10? This is Harem behaviour. What about the kids' minds? brains? Bah, I'm so upset I know I'll never sleep. here am I figuring out how many book-shelves my 8 week-old grand-daughter will need for all the books she received for her coming out party in Brooklyn the other day.

Can you tell I'm disgusted? I'm losing any faith I once had in feminism.

Ghost attacks! Very catchy. A ghost attack got us Viet Nam and another variation got us Iraq II. Stay tuned. This show is not over yet. It was taking its usual station break ads-one by SONY about its movie about N.K.
Substitute America's 1% for N.K. Enuf said.

Perhaps a better way for Gail Collins to phrase it would be "Rutherford B. Hayes stole back the election from Samuel Tilden." In true Deep South fashion, Tilden supporters stole the 1876 election by disenfranchising black votes. See, for instance, Ronald F. King's "Counting the Votes: South Carolina's Stolen Election of 1876" https://muse.jhu.edu/login?auth=0&type=summary&url=/journals/jou...

Another relevant factoid is that we've never had a woman President succeed another woman President. That's relevant because you've got to have the first woman President before one can be succeeded by another. Which means a lot of voters will view Sec Clinton, aside from her other qualifications, as having more historical dimension than merely another "white guy."

As for South Carolina ... Keep in mind that until the 2012 Republican Primary, the lure of South Carolina for GOP Presidential nominee candidates was it regularly predicted the eventual GOP nominee. In 2012, two thirds of South Carolina Republicans voted for the dog-whistle, racist candidate who hailed from Georgia. Also In 2012, the TV stations had been awash in campaign advertising money because of all the GOP candidates vying to become the South Carolina pick and thus presumptive GOP nominee. After that vote, however, those TV station general managers took a deep breath. In 2016, just how many GOP candidates are going to spend millions to win the title as the favorite of the white racists? South Carolina GOP voters made their collective vote irrelevant in national politics.
Seriously?  And how do you know your information is accurate?
A missed diplomatic opportunity?   That was the solution?  Maybe it's not too late...
By the time Obama leaves office, the US may not be the world's most powerful nation. We'll be lucky to remain in the top five.
This kind of sanction hurts US credibility. The US is the most powerful and influential nation in the world. There is no need to take a "proportional response" to every plausible offense.
HW appointed Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court.
A disaster if there ever was one.

George HW Bush did creat some sort of cosmic disaster.

He wasted the end of the Cold War. He refused to do "the vision thing" and let things drift.

The opportunities he squandered, the things he did not do, are the original cause of Cold War 2 now building, and of the long decline of the American economy for everyone but the very rich.

That was Buchanan's problem too, the things he did not do, the opportunities to head off the Civil War that he squandered.

So no, HW does not get a pass, even if we don't blame him for W. Which we should.

Sounds like Iraq all over again. But the issue is nothing if not this: "Why is America ready to enter another possible nuclear war situation with a country alleged to have (get this) hacked a private corporation's computers to gain access to "top secret" and "national defense secrets"? Or am I getting this story wrong?

Maybe there is much being kept from the American people again by the rouge secret CIA government OUR money funds? Maybe Hollywood actors and the movie industry in general are really nothing more than CIA operatives and assets?

Many Americans will come to the only reasonable alternative: Walt Disney is not dead! Neither is Elvis or Groucho. They all reside in a secret camp outside of Guantanamo where they are used to really torture our suspected terrorists.

It has the same logic: "None".

Could you imagine the response if the computer systems of Target, Macy's, Citibank, etc. were compromised by hackers? We know that is not possible unless done by aliens or some triangle of (whatever Bush II called it).

Saddam produced many documents to the USA and the UN showing Iraq had no weapons of mass destruction. America's leaders said it was a trick. A zillion dollars and many lost lives and guess what: no WMD found in Iraq except a few dump sites which poisoned our troops (and it might be mentioned, the military leadership denied it was harmful to those poor misused and misguided members of our armed forces).

Prepare for another war!
I'm also suspicious when lingo like "abortion on demand" is used early and often in a piece.

There’s a flip side to asking if abortion should be permitted when a woman “wants it for any reason”.

Does the same poll ask if abortion should be banned in all circumstances? Does it ask follow-up questions about penalties for violating such a ban? On whom? The woman? The person who performs the abortion? What penalties? Imprisonment? The death penalty, if you believe that abortion is murder?

Statistically reliable polling can be useful but, increasingly, pollsters ask simplistic questions that cater to a sound-bite culture. Either this poll was conducted in more depth that the writer failed to account for, or the poll itself was flawed. Either way, I get more than a little suspicious when an op-ed writer’s thesis is based on a single simplistic question.

Bullet 13 killed 9 yr-old Christina-Taylor Green in Tucson. It was only when the killer Loughner was changing his 33 bullet magazine that he was stopped. He killed 6 and injured 18.
If it's your kid, what calculation do *you* make?

Much as I dislike defending ANY Republican I cannot agree with your comment about GH Bush who was actually an intelligent and responsible politician; the last of the GOP line of moderate reality based politicians.
In particular it is this comment that irks me;
''He wasted the end of the Cold War. ..The opportunities he squandered, the things he did not do, are the original cause of Cold War 2 now building,''
Not true and one only has to listen to Gorbachov who stated clearly that the ONLY US politician who treated him with respect and attempted to live up to the spirit of the post 1989 era was GH Bush. It was he who persuaded Reagan and Thatcher to trust him leading to the agreement to let the Wall fall and more importantly it was he who attempted to prevent those who were most enthusiastic about abusing and betraying the agreements made to limit NATO expansion eastwards and to destroy the Russians from within. It was under Bill Clinton that the betrayal became full blown and support for the Russia destroying alcoholic Yeltsin who used tanks to fire on the Duma and corrupt oligarchs to dismember Russia both economically and literally (remember the mad nuclear armed Zhirinovsky and other potential fascists that alarmed the West so much it reversed course on that).
Bill Clinton and his wife are the Tony Blairs of the Democratic Party. They often support John 'Maddog' McCain in wrongly critisizing Obama for exercising restraint and intelligence in foreign affairs.

The results are yet to be determined. Lots of parents are grateful for this President's decision not to send their sons or daughters into harms way in support of tribal groups who refuse to fight themselves and look to American arms for their protection. Sorry you feel otherwise.  Korean Vat.

The Rickster is back.

Remember Iran-Contra?

How's about April Glaspie telling a certain leader of Iraq that America has no interest in Kuwait?

Looks as if Putin is in a little trouble of his own.

Historians will look back on the Obama presidency with a little more objectivity than knee-jerk rightist apologists like the Rickster, who is oh so anxious to throw a third Bush Junta on his fellow citizens as he waxes nostalgic through his rose-colored spectacles, forgetting how past events have a substantial impact on the present day.

History does not occur in a vacuum, Mr. Rick.

George HW Bush did creat some sort of cosmic disaster.

He wasted the end of the Cold War. He refused to do "the vision thing" and let things drift.

The opportunities he squandered, the things he did not do, are the original cause of Cold War 2 now building, and of the long decline of the American economy for everyone but the very rich.

That was Buchanan's problem too, the things he did not do, the opportunities to head off the Civil War that he squandered.

So no, HW does not get a pass, even if we don't blame him for W. Which we should.
I am responsible for my guns but, hard and thin as you try to stretch connection,  you can not make me responsible for anyone else.
Stu, I wish I had said that.  The South is our albatross.
Except Florida.  We still need a place to send old New Yorkers to so we can open up some apartments in the city.

It's Sat. 3:00 a.m. as I write this comment. Gail always makes me smile, so sleepless, I read her column for a lift. Then I read Stu's highest readers' pick comment. From where I sit, on my chair in the south, secure in the union, happy with the current president of my vote -- Stu's dismissal of a wide swath of our land pains me. I think of Lincoln (not Hillary). I search his quotes, then read his first inarguable address, a real eye-opener. Time for a cup of warm milk. Pete Seeger is playing in my head. Soothingly.
It's probably true that Hillary wouldn't follow in the footsteps of James Buchanan and allow any southern states to secede.  On the other hand, I'd vote for absolutely anyone who would.

Steve /Vermont - I am Army vet (enlisted 1966 at age 19) and also worked for PA State Police in their statistical research dept. at central HQ. Learned some interesting things there. The majority of criminals are not behind bars! Living in a "good quality" community makes a real difference. Steve, please be my neighbor!
On our street there is one retired Massachusetts State Trooper and several army and Marine vets. We have enough retired veterans here to field at least 2 combat brigades. The Villages is a very secure, peaceful and good place to retire. All of us abhor gun violence. However no one here is going to be a victim.

actually, it says 'arms'.
Even in the Founding Fathers' time, technology made advancements.

There's no reason to restrict the 2nd Amendment to muzzle loaders, any more than there is to restrict the 1st Amendment to pamphleteers and quill pens.
Love that last sentence!

If I am in the militia I don't want some popgun.
Why can't I have a missile launcher, a tank, or an anti-tank weapon if I can have a .45 for the purposes of having a civilian militia?

=========================

Actually lots of people in the US own tanks, it's perfectly legal. You should get out more. If you go to WWII re-enactors or air shows you will see the.

Also, Article I. Section 8 of the Constitution says that Congress can issue Letters of Marque, meaning that individual citizens can own warships. Congress issued these frequently during the War of 1812 and issued them as late as WWII.

"I'd love to hear one idea from the gun supporters how they are going to show some personal responsibility as a whole and exercise some self control."

The simple fact that 300 million guns don't sprout legs and sally forth to commit mass shootings on a daily basis tells you all you need to know about gun owners' "personal responsibility" and "self control", "as a whole".
